body:
Looks like you figured it out. Did you see [this](http://pandas-docs.github.io/pandas-docs-travis/dsintro.html#series-is-dict-like) section in the docs? Anything about that that's unclear? We could call it out in the text and show `(val == s).any()`.

Series is list-like (more `ndarray`-like), but also dict-like since it has labels, so there's an design choice to make. Perhaps I'm just used to it, but I think `in` checking for keys makes more sense.

Hi Tom,

Thanks for quick response and insight.

I didn't even think to look at the docs for this, is was obvious (sic) what it should do.

I use a lot more lists than dictionaries so I got caught in wrong assumptions.

 

--Len

 

From: Tom Augspurger [mailto:notifications@github.com] 
Sent: Saturday, June 03, 2017 6:25 PM
To: pandas-dev/pandas <pandas@noreply.github.com>
Cc: lengross <lengross@san.rr.com>; Author <author@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [pandas-dev/pandas] Behaviour of "in" on a series (#16594)

 

Looks like you figured it out. Did you see this <http://pandas-docs.github.io/pandas-docs-travis/dsintro.html#series-is-dict-like>  section in the docs? Anything about that that's unclear? We could call it out in the text and show (val == s).any().

Series is list-like (more ndarray-like), but also dict-like since it has labels, so there's an design choice to make. Perhaps I'm just used to it, but I think in checking for keys makes more sense.
